Porting

This section describes how to adapt the RKH to various platforms, which is a process called porting. RKH contains a clearly defined abstraction layer, which encapsulates all the platform-specific code and cleanly separates it from platform-neutral code.

Porting RKH implies to create the platform-dependent file, called rhhport.h. In this file must be defined the data types that uses RKH. The RKH directories and files are described in detail in Installation section. The next sections listed below describes the aspects to be considered:

  • Data types definitions
  • ROM allocator
  • Platform-dependent files
  • "rkhport.h" A port file example

Data types definitions

The RKH uses a set of integer quantities. That maybe machine or compiler dependent. These types must be defined in rkhport.h file as shown in "rkhport.h" A port file example.

  • rkhint8

    Denotes a signed integer type with a width of exactly 8 bits.
  • rkhint16

    Denotes a signed integer type with a width of exactly 16 bits.
  • rkhint32

    Denotes a signed integer type with a width of exactly 32 bits.
  • rkhuint8

    Denotes an unsigned integer type with a width of exactly 8 bits.
  • rkhuint16

    Denotes an unsigned integer type with a width of exactly 16 bits.
  • rkhuint32

    Denotes an unsigned integer type with a width of exactly 32 bits.
  • HUInt

    Denotes an unsigned integer type that is usually fastest to operate with among all integer types.
  • HInt

    Denotes a signed integer type that is usually fastest to operate with among all integer types.
Note:

The HUInt and HInt will normally be the natural size for a particular machine. These types designates an integer type that is usually fastest to operate with among all integer types.

ROM allocator

For declaring an object that its value will not be changed and that will be stored in ROM, must be defined in rkhport.h the rkhrom macro, as shown in "rkhport.h" A port file example.

#define rkhrom

The following listing shows an example of such definitions for a x86 platform and Visual C++ 2008.

typedef signed char     rkhint8;
typedef signed short    rkhint16;
typedef signed long     rkhint32;
typedef unsigned char   rkhuint8;
typedef unsigned short  rkhuint16;
typedef unsigned long   rkhuint32;

typedef unsigned int    HUInt;
typedef signed int      HInt;

#define rkhrom          const

Platform-dependent files

The header file rkhport.h adapts and configures RKH. This file has already discussed in Installation section. However, this section includes here again the explanation of this important file.

The \portable directory contains platform-independent header files to be used by RKH applications. Each platform-dependent file should be placed in a directory that represents the platform to be used, called port directory. Each port directory should be placed within \portable, i.e.: \portable\<platform>\rkhport.h. The Figure 2 RKH source directory shows three RKH port directories: \portable\cw08 (Codewarrior for Freescale S08), \portable\lnxgcc (Linux GCC), and \portable\vc08 (Visual C++ 2008).

Next, each rkhport.h must be referenced from rkhplat.h header file, located in \include directory. The idea behind conditional compilation is that a rkhport.h can be selectively compiled, depending upon whether a specific value has been defined. The next listing shows the rkhplat.h file according to \portable directory from Figure 2 RKH source directory, where ___CWS08__, ___LNXGCC__, and __VC__ are used to instruct the C/C++ compiler to include header files from the specific RKH port directory.

#if __CWS08__
    #include "..\portable\cw08\rkhport.h"
#elif __VC__
    #include "..\portable\vc08\rkhport.h"
#elif __LNXGCC__
    #include "lnxgcc/rkhport.h" 
#else
    #error "rkhplat.h: Missing platform definition."
#endif

The path of platform-dependent file must be relative.

"rkhport.h" A port file example

#include "rkhcfg.h"


/*
    Portable data types.

    The RKH uses a set of integer quantities. That maybe 
    machine or compiler dependent.

    Note:

    The 'HUInt' and 'HInt' will normally be the natural size 
    for a particular machine. These types designates an integer 
    type that is usually fastest to operate with among all integer 
    types.
 */

typedef signed char     rkhint8;
typedef signed short    rkhint16;
typedef signed long     rkhint32;
typedef unsigned char   rkhuint8;
typedef unsigned short  rkhuint16;
typedef unsigned long   rkhuint32;

typedef unsigned int    HUInt;
typedef signed int      HInt;


/*
    Declaring an object rkhrom announces that its value will
    not be changed and it will be stored in ROM.
 */

#define rkhrom          const
